_prev_prog_3.Description: The U.S. Air Force and Scott AFB have developed extensive release prevention and response programs for accidents involving hazardous materials. As with all Air Force installations, Scott AFB is required to follow an extensive list of existing Air Force policies and procedures designed to protect human health and the environment. The existing policies and procedures regarding the safe handling and storage of hazardous materials have been supplemented with a comprehensive Process Safety Management and Accidental Release Prevention Program for the Base.

1.0    OVERVIEW

Installation Background

Scott Air Force Base (SAFB) is located in St. Clair County, in the southwest portion of Illinois. To the northeast of the base is the community of Lebanon, to the southeast is Mascoutah, to the west are Belleville and Shiloh, and to the northwest is O'Fallon. MidAmerica Airport lies adjacent to the base to the north and east, and the remaining areas surrounding the base consists of some of the finest farmland within the state. The City of St. Louis is located only 20 miles to the west. Springfield, the capital of Illinois, is just over 100 miles north of the installation.

The total SAFB community is made up of more than 30,900 military and civilian personnel and their families living on and off base. SAFB employs nearly 12,000 persons; of whom 8,100 are military and 2,800 are civilian. In addition, there are also about 8,500 military retirees that the base serves.

The 375 Airlift Wing (AW) is the host unit at SAFB, fulfilling three primary missions:

Managing a domestic aeromedical evacuation system;
Commanding and supervising all operational support airlift within the United States; and
Conducting all Air Force C-9A aircraft qualification and instructor training.

SAFB is also the home of five headquarters, which are all supported by the 375 AW. These headquarters include: the United States Transportation Command, Air Mobility Command (18th Air Force), Air Force Communications Agency, Defense Information Technology Contracting Office, and Air Force Office of Special Investigations 3rd Field Investigations Region. In wartime or during other contingencies, the 375 AW is responsible for managing the aeromedical evacuation system that is designed to evacuate battle causalities from combat areas anywhere in the world. Major groups under the 375 AW include the 375 Operations Group, 375 Logistics Group, 375 Support Group, and the 375 Medical Group.

The 375 AW is also host to more than 40 on-base tenant units and another 30 units

Scott AFB is currently investigating the elimination of chlorine gas as a disinfection method at the WWTP.

2.0    RMP APPLICABILITY

Chlorine is the sole hazardous  chemical at Scott AFB that requires Scott AFB to maintain a Risk Management Plan and meet stringent reporting requirements. Chlorine is stored and used at the base Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) (Building 3292) for disinfection of wastewater discharges. Scott AFB stores six 2,000 lb. cylinders of chlorine gas at the wastewater treatment plant (Building 3292). A pair of 2,000 lb. cylinders is used for disinfection of the normal discharge from the WWTP, while a second pair is used for disinfection of by-pass wastewater during periods of excess flow. Therefore, a total of four 2,000-lb. cylinders are typically stored and used. All four cylinders are stored inside Building 3292. The significant quantity of chlorine stored in this process exceeds the RMP threshold for chlorine of 2,500 lbs. The cylinders are pigtailed together in pairs, with each pair of cylinders sharing a common control valve. This valve switches over automatically when the flow from one cylinder drops below a specified level. During normal operation, the main valves on all four cylinders remain open.

3.0    HAZARD (OFF-SITE ANALYSIS)

Worst-Case Release Scenario Analysis

This section summarizes the worst-case release scenario and public receptors associated with the chlorine process at the WWTP. Chlorine is stored at the WWTP near the southeast corner of the base property. Although the WWTP is located away from a majority of the base population, there are several public access areas nearby which would be of concern during a worst case scenario.

The RMP regulations define a worst-case release scenario or circle of concern as the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to an endpo

int. The worst case release scenario for toxic gases is assumed to be the total release of the single largest container in the process over a 10-minute duration. The worst case release scenario for the WWTP chlorine storage at Scott AFB would involve the failure of a chlorine cylinder containing 2,000 lbs. of chlorine. The chlorine would be released as a gas, and would form a vapor cloud that would travel in a downwind direction. If 2,000 lbs of chlorine gas were released over a 10-minute duration the endpoint would be 1.3 miles from the site of chlorine storage. 

A chlorine gas release from the chlorine storage area at the WWTP would affect public receptors during a worst-case release scenario. A public receptor is defined as "off-site residences, institutions (e.g., schools, hospitals) industrial, commercial, and office buildings, parks, or recreational areas inhabited or occupied by the public at any time without restriction by the stationary source where members of the public could be exposed to toxic concentrations, radiant heat, or overpressure, as a result of an accidental release" (40 CFR 68.3). For the purposes of this RMP, any building or area on Base where public access is allowed on an unrestricted basis was considered a public receptor. Public receptors at Scott AFB would include residences, recreational areas and a school. 

RMP regulations require an estimate of the residential population within the circle of concern for the worst-case scenario.  For chlorine, approximately 250 households would be impacted (980 persons) as a result of a worst-case scenario impacting the public areas listed in Table 3-1. The most sensitive receptor is the Southern Illinois University Research Center.

Alternative Release Scenario Analysis (ARS)

An ARS event is more probable than a worst-case scenario. The RMP Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants provides a standard table for an unmitigated release rate. The WWTP chlorine storage area is enclosed by a permanent st

ructure. The release of a liquefied gas from a 1-ton cylinder (under 98.5 psig) due to a sheered valve or line would result in a release rate of 30 lbs/min over a 10-minute period. The release would travel a distance of 0.10 and would reach the base jogging trail and the nearby playground.

4.0    PROGRAM LEVEL DETERMINATION

The EPA outlines three program levels for the RMP Prevention Program. Scott AFB's chlorine storage and usage at the WWTP qualifies as a Program Level 3 (the most strict) due to potentially impact to a number of public receptors. The chlorine process at the WWTP is also subject to OSHA's PSM (29 CFR 1910.119) with a threshold of 1,500 lbs.

Scott AFB also stores large amounts of propane. The maximum amount of propane stored at any one propane process is 37,000 lbs (Fire Training Facility). The amount of propane in this process does not exceed the 67,000-lbs. threshold and therefore the RMP rule does not apply to this source. 

5.0    PREVENTION PROGRAM

Scott AFB currently maintains a Prevention Program for this Program Level 3 process (chlorine) contained in a separate document entitled "Accident Prevention and Process Safety Management Program." This prevention program ensures that:

Process safety information is provided to all employees
Hazard analyses are completed every five years
Written operating procedures are followed by employees and kept up-to-date.
Initial and refresher training is provided to all employees
Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted
Mechanical integrity assurance program is in place
Hot work is permitted
Incidents are investigated

6.0    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

In addition to the prevention program, Scott AFB maintains a Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasure Plan (SPCC) to mitigate the effects of accidental releases should they occur. The Scott AFB Fire Department is staffed 24 hours per day, 365 days per year.

7.0    FIVE-YEAR HISTORY

Scott AFB has not experienced an accidental release of chlorine during the past fi

ve years. Scott AFB reports all releases of hazardous chemicals, regardless of size, to local and state regulatory agencies.

8.0    PLANNED CHANGES TO ELIMINATE CHLORINE STORAGE/USE

Scott AFB currently employs a safety checklist when changing chlorine gas cylinders at the WWTP. 

In an effort to eliminate RMP requirements and reduce risk of chlorine release, Scott AFB conducted a study to determine alternatives to chlorine disinfection at the WWTP. Three alternatives were developed with a focus on eliminating chlorine storage: (1) changing chlorine storage cylinder size to reduce storage capacity to under the 2,500-lbs threshold, (2) utilize a substitute disinfection chemical and (3) utilize a non-chemical disinfection technology. 

SAIC interviewed several WWTP personnel to identify any solutions to reducing chlorine storage cylinder size. SAIC also contact gas supply vendors to inquire into the availability of smaller storage cylinders. Chlorine gas is supplied commercially in K-size and 1-ton cylinders. The K-size cylinders were considered inappropriate in capacity to handle large flows of wastewater at the WWTP.

SAIC also investigated alternative chemicals for wastewater disinfection. Substitute chemicals were costly and would require costly infrastructure investments. Such chemicals included ozone, peroxone and others.

The preferred cost-effective solution to eliminate chlorine use at the WWTP is the implementation of ultra-violet (UV) disinfection technology. The UV study is attached to the "Applicability Determination Statement" (SAIC, 2004) as an appendix and is under review by the 375th CES/CEV for implementation. If this alternative were implemented, Scott AFB would no longer be subject to RMP regulatory requirements.

Scott AFB 375th CES/CEV will program/budget the appropriate alternative approach to eliminate chlorine as a pollution prevention project.

Scott AFB has no future plans to introduce additional chemicals that would require sustainment of a R

MP.

9.0    RMP MANAGEMENT PLAN

A RMP management structure must be established to successfully implement  and sustain the RMP. In addition, a primary point of contact with overall authority for RMP implementation must be assigned. This primary POC will report to the 375th CES/CEV as required.

The RMP Team will be responsible for implementing, overseeing and updating the RMP. Updates will be conducted whenever:

* A newly regulated substance is first listed by the EPA,
* A regulated substance is above its threshold for the first time,
* A revised PHA, hazard review or consequence analysis due to a changed process,
* Program Level changes,
* The facility is no longer subject to RMP requirements (de-registration).

The RMP Team would assume responsibility for meeting RMP requirements until use and storage of chlorine liquefied gas has been eliminated at the WWTP.
